title: Jeremiah Imprisoned
shortSummary: Jeremiah 37 recounts the early reign of King Zedekiah and the prophet Jeremiah’s continued ministry during the Babylonian siege of Jerusalem. Despite Jeremiah’s warnings from God, the people and their leaders reject his message, resulting in his imprisonment. This chapter highlights the tension between divine truth and human rebellion.
timeline: c. 597 BC - Early reign of King Zedekiah during the Babylonian siege of Jerusalem

keyCharacters.name: Zedekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who reigned after Coniah; he seeks Jeremiah’s counsel but ultimately does not fully obey God’s warnings.

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet of God who faithfully delivers God’s messages despite opposition, imprisonment, and personal suffering.

keyCharacters.name: Jehucal
keyCharacters.description: Son of Shelemiah, sent by King Zedekiah to Jeremiah to request prayer for the nation.

keyCharacters.name: Irijah
keyCharacters.description: A captain of the guard who arrests Jeremiah under suspicion of defecting to the Chaldeans.

definitions.definition: Another name for the Babylonians, the empire besieging Jerusalem during this period.
A dark, underground prison cell where Jeremiah was confined.
The king of Egypt, whose army briefly caused the Babylonians to lift their siege of Jerusalem.
A humble and earnest prayer or request made to God.

outline.heading: Zedekiah’s Reign and Rejection of God’s Word
outline.description: Zedekiah becomes king of Judah but, like his predecessors, neither he nor the people heed Jeremiah’s prophetic warnings from the LORD.

outline.heading: Pharaoh’s Army and the Temporary Lifting of the Siege
outline.description: Pharaoh’s army advances from Egypt, causing the Babylonian Chaldeans to temporarily withdraw from Jerusalem, allowing Jeremiah some freedom.

outline.heading: God’s Warning of Babylon’s Return and Jerusalem’s Destruction
outline.description: God instructs Jeremiah to warn that Pharaoh’s help is futile and that the Babylonians will return to capture and burn Jerusalem.

outline.heading: Jeremiah Arrested and Imprisoned
outline.description: Jeremiah leaves Jerusalem but is arrested by Irijah on false charges of defecting to the enemy and is beaten and imprisoned.

outline.heading: Secret Meeting with King Zedekiah and Continued Imprisonment
outline.description: Zedekiah secretly questions Jeremiah about God’s word; Jeremiah confirms the coming Babylonian captivity. Despite this, Jeremiah remains imprisoned under harsh conditions.

application: Trust God’s word even when it is unpopular or leads to personal suffering, as Jeremiah did.
Pray earnestly for leaders and those in authority, following Zedekiah’s example of seeking God’s guidance.
Do not deceive yourself by hoping for worldly help that contradicts God’s promises; rely fully on His sovereign plan.
Respond to opposition with faithfulness and integrity, maintaining a clear conscience before God and man.

keyVerses.text: And Zedekiah the king sent Jehucal the son of Shelemiah and Zephaniah the son of Maaseiah the priest to the prophet Jeremiah, saying, Pray now unto the LORD our God for us.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the king’s recognition of the need for God’s intervention through prayer, highlighting the importance of seeking God in times of crisis.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the LORD; Deceive not yourselves, saying, The Chaldeans shall surely depart from us: for they shall not depart.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn warning against false hope, emphasizing that God’s judgment through Babylon is certain and must be acknowledged.

keyVerses.text: Then Zedekiah the king sent, and took him out: and the king asked him secretly in his house, and said, Is there any word from the LORD? And Jeremiah said, There is: for, said he, thou shalt be delivered into the hand of the king of Babylon.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the king’s fear and Jeremiah’s faithful proclamation of God’s judgment, underscoring the tension between divine truth and royal authority.

keyVerses.text: Then Zedekiah the king commanded that they should commit Jeremiah into the court of the prison, and that they should give him daily a piece of bread out of the bakers' street, until all the bread in the city were spent. Thus Jeremiah remained in the court of the prison.
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates Jeremiah’s continued suffering and isolation, yet God’s provision through the king’s command, illustrating God’s sustaining grace amid trials.
